elements.title: Horvat 'Eqed (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that excavations at Horvat 'Eqed (pictured) uncovered coinage and hiding complexes dating from the Bar Kokhba revolt, as well as arrowheads, armor scales, slingshots, and ballistae?

elements.title: Spider (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Spider began making alternative music because she felt that not enough Black women were doing so?

elements.title: Southern Railway Building (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the trowel and gavel used at the cornerstone-laying ceremony for the Southern Railway Building were previously used by George Washington for the U.S. Capitol?

elements.title: Gherardo Gambelli (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Gherardo Gambelli, the incoming archbishop of Florence, served as a prison chaplain in Chad for over a decade?

elements.title: Centurion C-RAM (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Centurion C-RAM can fire 4500 rounds per minute?

elements.title: Rahmad Mas'ud (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Indonesian politician Rahmad Mas'ud received his master's degree simultaneously with four of his siblings?

elements.title: Atlantic hurricane activity in 1993 (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that all Atlantic hurricane activity in 1993 ceased two full months before the season officially ended?

elements.title: Chuck Eisenmann (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Chuck Eisenmann went from professionally pitching in baseball to owning and training the dogs that starred on the Canadian television series The Littlest Hobo?

elements.title: bed of nails (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Richard Garwin proposed using a bed of nails to protect the Minuteman missile silos from attack?
